DM11:10am

.Ms Mercer appeared to bring a level of discipline and accuracy to Carillion’s accounting policies that had been severely lacking. On her return, she quickly spotted an anomaly in the way the company was classifying receivable balances on construction contracts,327 calling it “sloppy accounting”.328 The board agreed that her concerns should be investigated, but shied away from a full independent review. Instead, the board invited the company’s auditor, KPMG, to review work that it had previously audited and approved. KPMG agreed with the board’s conclusion that although Carillion had misclassified assets, it had not misstated revenue. That review did, however, act as the trigger for the wider contract review that led to the £845 million provision in July 2017.329

pancakes or waffles though I will still keep an eye out for it nonetheless
11:10 am
DM11:10am

She demonstrated a willingness to speak the truth and challenge the status quo, fundamental qualities in a director that were not evident in any of her colleagues.

DM11:10am

Richard Adam, however

DM11:11am

The dominant personality in Carillion’s finance department was Richard Adam. He was in charge for most of the last decade, and received a final pay package of £1.1 million in December 2016.334 Andrew Dougal said Mr Adam “exercised tight control over the entire finance function, had extensive influence through the Group” and “was defensive in relation to some challenges in board meetings”.335 His approach to negotiating with the pension Trustee similarly suggested someone who exerted control and refused to compromise. It is impossible to imagine that any significant accounting policy decisions were made without his prior approval.

DM11:18am

The President (assuming he had the document) may have an interest in acting as a whistle-blower once he realised how disruptive for Italy the contract is, and especially for the sustainability of public finances and the attitude towards the euro. In other words, he may have leaked the document to allow financial markets to react, effectively acting as a warning against the policies of the would-be government. It would be a sort of ‘homoeopathic crisis’ to avoid the more serious one that would emerge from the implementation of the proposed policies. No matter who did it, this is a bombshell, and it reveals the real attitude of the two parties. It also shows the incompetence of these politicians, as some proposals are merely unfeasible or plain wrong.

It also calls for a renegotiation of Italy’s contribution to the EU budget and renegotiation of EU treaties. The real bombshell, however, is on page 38. They want to ask the ECB to “freeze” and “cancel” Italian government bonds in its portfolio (250bn at the end of QE). There is also a chapter on “reforming the Bank of Italy”, although it is still blank.

DM11:22am

The main reason why is that the peak of the euro area debt crisis was several years ago. Italy is now in a much healthier place. It has a current account surplus, a growing economy, slowing inflation and the ECB operating with an exceptionally loose monetary policy. The market would need to be facing a severe global slowdown before crisis correlations return, and Italy would probably not be our biggest worry if they did.

PM11:46am

A tariff cap...and then still more competition
Centrica in 2018: Most likely the last year before the tariff cap. We see £525m of EBIT in British Gas residential energy, and £782m in UK Home.

Threats: The tariff cap. The UK Government is still using the CMA's 2016 £1.4bn of detriment number when talking about tariffs (and its April Green Paper focuses on the higher prices it sees vulnerable customers as paying), even though Centrica (and peers) have taken out a lot of costs in the past couple of years. At the same time the betting industry shows that policy regulatory changes can usher in greater, not less, competition - the competitive backdrop could worsen in 2019 and beyond.

Opportunities: Customer engagement and service range quality will only matter more. If legacy suppliers can transform their cost base, then superior brands and superior offerings (Connected Home for B2C, and Distributed Energy products for B2B) will be a competitive advantage.

MS Centrica medium term outlook: We expect to see competition as tough in 2019 and customer numbers continuing to decline for Centrica. Cost cutting can only offset this pinch so far. We forecast EBIT of £~330m in 2019, and declining slowly thereafter.

11:59 am
DM11:59am

Here's Shore

DM11:59am

The board is guiding to full year EBIT margins of 18% against ours and consensus of above 19%. The guidance also suggests that EBIT margins for next year will be at a similar level. The reason for the slippage is one that we have been highlighting for some time – the under-recovery of build cost inflation, an issue that the house builders have suggested is not a problem, yet at least, because prices were still rising enough to recover this. We had expected this to become an issue but only from CY2019 so this is a shock.

DM11:59am

Crest is making comments about pricing being more difficult at its generally slightly higher price point than that of other house builders (average price for open market sales is £439k versus something in the high £200k range for most other house builders not Crest does have a heavy southern bias) and sells more to those who are also selling a house in the second hand market – very few sales are to first time buyers where help to buy has its greatest impact. However, it would be wrong to think that this drag from the existing homes market and the inability to under-recovery costs is a problem unique to Crest.

DM12:00pm

Forecasts will have to be lowered. For the current year the drop in EBIT to 18% suggests a reduction in PBT from £226m to nearer £210m. As margins are guided to be flat in FY2019F, but bearing in mind we were already forecasting a fall in margins, we are probably looking at a move from £257m to £240m.
